list_definition.definition: a man on duty at the door of a hotel, store etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The doorman was standing outside the entrance to the club.

list_ex_of_english: It should then be an offence for a nightclub owner to hire a doorman who did not possess an approved licence.
One of my concerns relates to drug dealing by doormen and the control of drug dealing in night-clubs.
It led to the unemployment of caretakers, doormen and cleaners.
We also came into direct contact with one doorman, one youth who revolved the revolving doors, two cloakroom attendants, one lift man, one welcoming head-waiter and a farewelling one.
Does he agree that in many circumstances it is feasible that instructions will be given by the owner of the night-club to the doormen?
The doorman was always polite and friendly.
However, clearly the doormen would be at risk of facing criminal prosecution if they exceeded their authority.
Will doormen in hotels be covered by licences?
